Secure Weighted Aggregation for Federated Learning

Jiale Guo Both authors contributed equally to this research. 11 Ziyao Liu Secure Weighted Aggregation for Federated Learning 11 Kwok-Yan Lam 11 Jun Zhao 11 Yiqiang Chen 22 Chaoping Xing 33
Abstract

The pervasive adoption of Internet-connected digital services has led to a growing concern in the personal data privacy of their customers. On the other hand, machine learning (ML) techniques have been widely adopted by digital service providers to improve operational productivity and customer satisfaction. ML inevitably accesses and processes users’ personal data, which could potentially breach the relevant privacy protection regulations if not performed carefully. The situation is exacerbated by the cloud-based implementation of digital services when user data are captured and stored in distributed locations, hence aggregation of the user data for ML could be a serious breach of privacy regulations. In this backdrop, Federated Learning (FL) is an emerging area that allows ML on distributed data without the data leaving their stored location. Typically, FL starts with an initial global model, with each datastore uses its local data to compute the gradient based on the global model, and uploads their gradients (instead of the data) to an aggregation server, at which the global model is updated and then distributed to the local data stores iteratively. However, depending on the nature of the digital services, data captured at different locations may carry different significance to the business operation, hence a weighted aggregation will be highly desirable for enhancing the quality of the FL-learned model. Furthermore, to prevent leakage of user data from the aggregated gradients, cryptographic mechanisms are needed to allow secure aggregation of FL. Previous works on FL mainly focus on the FL framework and mechanisms for weighted aggregation. In this paper, we propose a privacy-enhanced FL scheme for supporting secure weighted aggregation. Besides, by devising a verification protocol based on Zero-Knowledge Proof (ZKP), the proposed scheme is capable of guarding against fraudulent messages from FL participants. Experimental results show that our scheme is practical and secure. Compared to existing FL approaches, our scheme achieves secure weighted aggregation with an additional security guarantee against fraudulent messages with an affordable 1.2 times runtime overheads and 1.3 times communication costs.

Keywords:
federated learning secure aggregation data disparity evaluation homomorphic encryption zero-knowledge proof

1 Introduction

The pervasive adoption of Internet-connected digital services has led to a growing concern in personal data privacy of their customers. On the other hand, machine learning (ML) techniques have been widely adopted by digital service providers to improve operational productivity and customer satisfaction. ML inevitably accesses and processes users’ personal data, which could potentially breach the relevant privacy protection regulations if not performed carefully. The situation is exacerbated by the cloud-based implementation of digital services when user data are captured and stored in distributed locations, hence aggregation of the user data for ML could be a serious breach of privacy regulations. Such a scenario where multiple data stores (or custodians) jointly solve a machine learning problem while complying with privacy regulations has attracted tremendous attention from academia and industry. Privacy-preserving techniques such as differential privacy (DP), fully homomorphic encryption (FHE), and secure multi-party computation (MPC) are widely believed to be promising approaches to achieve this goal. However, it is well known that DP requires a tradeoff between data usability and privacy [21], while MPC and HE offer cryptographic privacy with high communication or computation overheads.

In this backdrop, Federated Learning (FL) [13] is an emerging area that allows ML on distributed data without the data leaving their stored location. For example, an international bank typically has data centres in multiple countries, domestic regulations of each country may not allow the bank to move customer data out of the jurisdiction; hence FL will be a useful approach to allow ML overall distributed data through the participation of all local data centres. Typically, FL starts with an initial global model, with each data store (in the respective data centre) uses its local data to compute the gradient based on the global model, and uploads their gradients (instead of the data) to an aggregation server, at which the global model is updated and then distributed to the local data stores iteratively.

However, depending on the nature of digital services and FL systems, data captured at different locations may exhibit disparity. For instance, digital inclusion may vary from country to country and, due to the need for service localization, the type of collected data may also be different. Besides, the technical competence of local personnel may also vary, thus ML at local data stores may suffer from label biases. This means that different local datasets may have different significance to the global FL model, and thus the organization’s business operation. Hence a weighted aggregation scheme will be highly desirable for enhancing the quality of the FL-learned model. In this case, the central server is required to evaluate the disparity across all local datasets in order to compute the weightings, and then aggregate all the clients’ locally trained models according to their weights. To calculate the weight, measurements on data size and data quality are widely adopted. For example, in the most popular FL approach FedAvg [15], the locally trained models from users are weighted by the percentage of their data size in the total training data. Based on FedAvg, the authors in [5] further evaluate clients’ label quality by calculating the mutual cross-entropy between data and models of both the central server and clients. Although approaches in previous works resulted in a good performance in dealing with disparity across local datasets and improved the accuracy of the global FL model, they did not address the privacy guarantee for clients’ data.

Furthermore, from the angle of privacy protection, digital service providers need to address another important issue of FL, that is the feasibility of information leakage from the gradients. As pointed out in [22], it is possible to derive the local training data from the publicly shared gradients, or models, in a multi-node machine learning system such as an FL system. Experimental results showed that such deep leakage from gradients allows the attacker to achieve pixel-wise accurate recovery for images and token-wise matching for texts in common computer vision and natural language processing tasks. Secure aggregation schemes [4, 1] aim to deal with this issue. However, during the FL process, the distributed data stores and the central server may still receive fraudulent messages due to insider frauds, which may affect the accuracy of the global FL model. For example, consider an enterprise FL system. FL participants are required to annotate the data with labels, and then train their local models with the labeled data. The competence and productivity of each FL participant will have a non-trivial impact on the label quality of the training data, which should understandably carry different weights in the overall ML. The weights are calculated by the data disparity evaluation scheme as mentioned earlier. The larger weight usually serves as an indicator of the higher quality, hence the competence and productivity of the local personnel, and vice versa. In this case, an incompetent or dishonest employee may manipulate the computed weight and send fraudulent messages (by manipulating the weights) during data disparity evaluation so as to obtain a larger weight. In other cases, the FL participant may upload a fraudulent model to affect the distribution of the global FL model in the current FL round in order to increase its weight in the next FL round [2]. Note that such an issue regarding fraudulent messages can be generalized to any FL system.

In order to address the aforementioned issues, we propose a secure weighted aggregation scheme to deal with both data disparity, data privacy, and dishonest participants (who send fraudulent messages to manipulate the computed weights) in FL systems. Our scheme leverages on HE and zero-knowledge proof (ZKP), and combines with a dropout-resilient secure aggregation scheme. To summarize, our contributions are the following:

  • •

    By leveraging on HE, the proposed scheme achieves data disparity evaluation in a privacy-preserving manner.

  • •

    By devising a verification protocol based on ZKP, the proposed scheme is capable of guarding against fraudulent messages from being received by FL participants.

  • •

    The proposed scheme can be generalized to any data disparity evaluation scheme for secure weighted aggregation in FL.

  • •

    Compared to existing FL schemes, experimental results show that our scheme achieves secure weighted aggregation with an additional security guarantee against fraudulent messages with an affordable 1.2 times of runtime overheads and 1.3 times communication costs.

Organisation of the paper: The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we introduce the preliminaries and supporting protocols. In Section 3, we describe the rationales for secure weighted aggregation together with a high-level overview, and the threat model. Then we give a detailed description of our proposed scheme, and discuss its privacy and security in Section 4. Experimental results are present in Section 5. Finally, we discuss related works in Section 6, and conclude and outline several directions for future research in Section 7. More background, detailed proofs and tolerance analysis are given in the Appendix.

2 Preliminaries and Supporting Protocols

This section briefly describes the preliminaries of federated learning, data disparity evaluation, secure aggregation, and related cryptographic protocols used in this work.

A typical FL scheme works by repeating the following steps until training is stopped, determined by the model engineer monitoring the training process.

  1. 1.

    User selection: In round t𝑡t, the server S𝑆S selects a fraction of users 𝒰t⊆𝒰subscript𝒰𝑡𝒰\mathcal{U}_{t}\subseteq\mathcal{U}.

  2. 2.

    Broadcast: The server S𝑆S broadcasts the current global model Mtsubscript𝑀𝑡M_{t} to the selected users.

  3. 3.

    User computation: Each selected user ui∈𝒰tsubscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝒰𝑡u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}_{t} trains a local model on their dataset Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}, and calculates the update Mtisuperscriptsubscript𝑀𝑡𝑖M_{t}^{i}.

  4. 4.

    Model aggregation: The server S𝑆S collects local updates from users in the current round and computes global update according to an aggregation method, e.g., in [15], the local update of user is weighted by the percentage of their data size in the whole training data.

  5. 5.

    Model update: The server S𝑆S updates the global model such that ℳt+1←ℳts←subscriptℳ𝑡1superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑡𝑠\mathcal{M}_{t+1}\leftarrow\mathcal{M}_{t}^{s}.

2.3 Data Disparity Evaluation

As data size and data quality vary across local datasets, an evaluation scheme for data disparity is essential in the FL system. In this work, we improve the label quality evaluation scheme proposed in [5] to illustrate how to construct an interactive evaluation scheme in a privacy-preserving manner. Note that this scheme can be generalized to any data disparity evaluation scheme for federated learning.

By maintaining a small set of benchmark dataset 𝒟ssubscript𝒟𝑠\mathcal{D}_{s}, the central server S𝑆S is allowed to quantify the credibility Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i} of each local dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} by computing the mutual cross-entropy Eisubscript𝐸𝑖E_{i}. In specific, mutual cross-entropy Eisubscript𝐸𝑖E_{i} evaluates both the performance of the global model ℳℳ\mathcal{M} on the local dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, i.e., L​Li𝐿subscript𝐿𝑖LL_{i}, and the performance of the local model of the user ℳisubscriptℳ𝑖\mathcal{M}_{i} on the benchmark dataset 𝒟ssubscript𝒟𝑠\mathcal{D}_{s}, i.e., L​Si𝐿subscript𝑆𝑖LS_{i}, which is given by:

Eisubscript𝐸𝑖\displaystyle E_{i} =L​Si+L​Liabsent𝐿subscript𝑆𝑖𝐿subscript𝐿𝑖\displaystyle=LS_{i}+LL_{i}
L​Si𝐿subscript𝑆𝑖\displaystyle LS_{i} =−∑(xs,ys)∈𝒟sys​log⁡P​(y∣xs;ℳi)absentsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑠subscript𝑦𝑠subscript𝒟𝑠subscript𝑦𝑠𝑃conditional𝑦subscript𝑥𝑠subscriptℳ𝑖\displaystyle=-\sum_{(x_{s},y_{s})\in\mathcal{D}_{s}}y_{s}\log P\left(y\mid x_{s};\mathcal{M}_{i}\right)
L​Li𝐿subscript𝐿𝑖\displaystyle LL_{i} =−∑(xu,yu)∈𝒟iyu​log⁡P​(y∣xu;ℳ)absentsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑢subscript𝑦𝑢subscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝑦𝑢𝑃conditional𝑦subscript𝑥𝑢ℳ\displaystyle=-\sum_{(x_{u},y_{u})\in\mathcal{D}_{i}}y_{u}\log P\left(y\mid x_{u};\mathcal{M}\right)

Then the weight of user i𝑖i’s model can be defined as:

wi=ni​Ci∑j=1Knj​Ci​ where ​Ci=1−eα​Ei∑j=1Keα​Ejsubscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝐶𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾subscript𝑛𝑗subscript𝐶𝑖 where subscript𝐶𝑖1superscript𝑒𝛼subscript𝐸𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾superscript𝑒𝛼subscript𝐸𝑗w_{i}=\frac{n_{i}C_{i}}{\sum_{j=1}^{K}n_{j}C_{i}}\text{ where }C_{i}=1-\frac{e^{\alpha E_{i}}}{\sum_{j=1}^{K}e^{\alpha E_{j}}}

Here nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} is the size of the dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, K𝐾K is the number of users, and α𝛼\alpha is a hyper-parameter for normalization. These weights can be used in subsequent weighted aggregation to obtain the new global model as ∑i=1Kwi​ℳisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝑤𝑖subscriptℳ𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{K}w_{i}\mathcal{M}_{i}.

2.4 Secure Aggregation

Secure aggregation scheme [4] enables a server S𝑆S to compute a sum z𝑧z of the locally trained models {ℳu}u∈𝒰subscriptsubscriptℳ𝑢𝑢𝒰\{\mathcal{M}_{u}\}_{u\in\mathcal{U}} from a set of users 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} in a private and dropout-robust manner, when the number of non-dropout users is greater than a threshold t𝑡t. The improved version [1] further reduce the communication overheads by having each user communicates across only a subset of users rather than all the users. We denote such aggregation schemes as z←πS​e​c​A​g​g​(𝒰,{ℳi},t)←𝑧subscript𝜋𝑆𝑒𝑐𝐴𝑔𝑔𝒰subscriptℳ𝑖𝑡z\leftarrow\pi_{SecAgg}(\mathcal{U},\{\mathcal{M}_{i}\},t). Specifically, the illustrative scheme can be summarized as follows:

Mask Generation ({R},𝒰1)←πM​G​(t,𝒰)←𝑅subscript𝒰1subscript𝜋𝑀𝐺𝑡𝒰(\{R\},\mathcal{U}_{1})\leftarrow\pi_{MG}(t,\mathcal{U}): Each user u∈𝒰𝑢𝒰u\in\mathcal{U} generates a random matrix R𝑅R to mask the local model ℳℳ\mathcal{M}, and the set of alive users after mask generation is denoted as 𝒰1subscript𝒰1\mathcal{U}_{1}. In specifc, the matrix R𝑅R is generated using pseudorandom generator (PRG) [3] that R=Rb+Rs𝑅subscript𝑅𝑏subscript𝑅𝑠R=R_{b}+R_{s} which consists of (i) a self-chosen matrix Rb=PRG​(bu)subscript𝑅𝑏PRGsubscript𝑏𝑢R_{b}=\text{PRG}(b_{u}) where busubscript𝑏𝑢b_{u} is a self-chosen seed by the user u𝑢u, and (ii) the sum of pairwise matrices with all other users Rs=PRG​(∑u<vsu,v−∑u>vsv,u)subscript𝑅𝑠PRGsubscript𝑢𝑣subscript𝑠𝑢𝑣subscript𝑢𝑣subscript𝑠𝑣𝑢R_{s}=\text{PRG}(\sum_{u<v}s_{u,v}-\sum_{u>v}s_{v,u}) (assume a total order on users) where su,vsubscript𝑠𝑢𝑣s_{u,v} is the seed that both user u𝑢u and v𝑣v agree on. To handle the dropout users, the self-chosen seed busubscript𝑏𝑢b_{u} and the pairwise seed su,vsubscript𝑠𝑢𝑣s_{u,v}, are secretly shared among all users using a t𝑡t-out-of-|𝒰|𝒰|\mathcal{U}| Shamir threshold secret sharing scheme.

Masked Model Aggregation (y,𝒰2)←πM​M​A({ℳ}(y,\mathcal{U}_{2})\leftarrow\pi_{MMA}(\{\mathcal{M}\}, {R}𝑅\{R\}, 𝒰1),t\mathcal{U}_{1}),t. Each user u∈𝒰1𝑢subscript𝒰1u\in\mathcal{U}_{1} computes and uploads its masked local model yu=ℳ+Rsubscript𝑦𝑢ℳ𝑅y_{u}=\mathcal{M}+R. Then the server collects all masked models from the set of alive users, denoted as 𝒰2⊆𝒰1subscript𝒰2subscript𝒰1\mathcal{U}_{2}\subseteq\mathcal{U}_{1}, and computes the aggregation y=∑u∈𝒰2yu𝑦subscript𝑢subscript𝒰2subscript𝑦𝑢y=\sum_{u\in\mathcal{U}_{2}}y_{u}. Note that the number of alive users |𝒰2|subscript𝒰2|\mathcal{U}_{2}| should be larger than the threshold t𝑡t, otherwise abort.

Model Aggregation Recovery z←πM​A​R​(y,𝒰1,𝒰2,t)←𝑧subscript𝜋𝑀𝐴𝑅𝑦subscript𝒰1subscript𝒰2𝑡z\leftarrow\pi_{MAR}(y,\mathcal{U}_{1},\mathcal{U}_{2},t). Each user u∈𝒰2𝑢subscript𝒰2u\in\mathcal{U}_{2} sends its Shamir shares of busubscript𝑏𝑢b_{u} and each user u∈𝒰1𝑢subscript𝒰1u\in\mathcal{U}_{1} sends its Shamir shares of su,vsubscript𝑠𝑢𝑣s_{u,v} to the server. After receiving the shares of busubscript𝑏𝑢b_{u} and su,vsubscript𝑠𝑢𝑣s_{u,v} of which the number is greater than the threshold t𝑡t, the server reconstructs corresponding busubscript𝑏𝑢b_{u} and su,vsubscript𝑠𝑢𝑣s_{u,v} to recover the final aggregated result z𝑧z as:

z=y−∑u∈𝒰2𝖯𝖱𝖦​(bu)+∑u∈𝒰1/𝒰2,v∈𝒰2𝖯𝖱𝖦​(su,v)𝑧𝑦subscript𝑢subscript𝒰2𝖯𝖱𝖦subscript𝑏𝑢subscriptformulae-sequence𝑢subscript𝒰1subscript𝒰2𝑣subscript𝒰2𝖯𝖱𝖦subscript𝑠𝑢𝑣z=y-\sum_{u\in\mathcal{U}_{2}}\mathsf{PRG}(b_{u})+\sum_{u\in\mathcal{U}_{1}/\mathcal{U}_{2},v\in\mathcal{U}_{2}}\mathsf{PRG}(s_{u,v})

Note that for simplicity, we omit some cryptographic primitives such as the signature scheme, Diffie-Hellman key agreement scheme, and describe only the illustrative secure aggregation scheme for semi-honest setting. We refer interested readers to [4, 1] for the details.

2.5 Cryptographic Tools

We now introduce the cryptographic building blocks used in our scheme.

2.5.1 Paillier Crypto-system

Paillier Crypto-system is a probabilistic asymmetric encryption scheme with additive homomorphic properties [17] consisting of a tuple of algorithms as follows:

  • •

    𝖧𝖤.𝖪𝖾𝗒𝖦𝖾𝗇​(p,q)formulae-sequence𝖧𝖤𝖪𝖾𝗒𝖦𝖾𝗇𝑝𝑞\mathsf{HE.KeyGen}(p,q): For large primes p𝑝p and q𝑞q that gcd(pq,(p−1)(q−1)=1gcd(pq,(p-1)(q-1)=1, compute n=p⋅q𝑛⋅𝑝𝑞n=p\cdot q and λ=l​c​m​(p−1,q−1)𝜆𝑙𝑐𝑚𝑝1𝑞1\lambda=lcm(p-1,q-1).   • •

    𝖧𝖤.𝖤𝗇𝖼​(p​k,m,r)formulae-sequence𝖧𝖤𝖤𝗇𝖼𝑝𝑘𝑚𝑟\mathsf{HE.Enc}(pk,m,r): For message m∈ℤN𝑚subscriptℤ𝑁m\in\mathbb{Z}_{N}, taking the public key p​k𝑝𝑘pk and a random number r∈ℤN∗𝑟superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑁r\in\mathbb{Z}_{N}^{*}, output a ciphertext c=𝖤𝗇𝖼​(m)=gm​rn(modn2)𝑐𝖤𝗇𝖼𝑚annotatedsuperscript𝑔𝑚superscript𝑟𝑛moduloabsentsuperscript𝑛2c=\mathsf{Enc}(m)=g^{m}r^{n}\quad(\bmod\ n^{2}).

For simplicity, we sometimes abuse the notation E​n​c𝐸𝑛𝑐Enc and D​e​c𝐷𝑒𝑐Dec instead of 𝖧𝖤.𝖤𝗇𝖼(pk,m,\mathsf{HE.Enc}(pk,m, r)r) and 𝖧𝖤.𝖣𝖾𝖼​(s​k,c)formulae-sequence𝖧𝖤𝖣𝖾𝖼𝑠𝑘𝑐\mathsf{HE.Dec}(sk,c) when the context is clear. Paillier supports homomorphic addition between two ciphertext such that 𝖤𝗇𝖼(m1)⋅𝖤𝗇𝖼(m2)(modn2)=𝖤𝗇𝖼(m1+m2\mathsf{Enc}(m_{1})\cdot\mathsf{Enc}(m_{2})(\bmod\ n^{2})=\mathsf{Enc}(m_{1}+m_{2} (modn2))(\bmod\ n^{2})), and homomorphic multiplication between a plaintext and a ciphertext such that (𝖤𝗇𝖼​(m1))m2superscript𝖤𝗇𝖼subscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2(\mathsf{Enc}(m_{1}))^{m_{2}} (modn2)=𝖤𝗇𝖼(m1m2(modn))(\bmod\ {n^{2}})=\mathsf{Enc}(m_{1}m_{2}\ (\bmod\ n)). We denote ⊞⊞\boxplus with the homomorphic addition between two ciphertexts, and ⊠⊠\boxtimes with the homomorphic multiplication between a ciphertext and a plaintext. In addition, Paillier crypto-system provides semantic security against chosen-plaintext attacks (IND-CPA) (see Appendix 0.B) such that an adversary will be unable to distinguish pairs of ciphertexts based on the message they encrypt [17].

2.5.2 Zero Knowledge Proof of Plaintext Knowledge.

A zero-knowledge proof of plaintext knowledge (ZKPoPK) algorithm enables a prover to prove the knowledge of a plaintext m𝑚m of some ciphertext C=E​n​c​(m)𝐶𝐸𝑛𝑐𝑚C=Enc(m) to a verifier in a given public encryption scheme, without revealing anything about message m𝑚m [10]. Following the Paillier-based ZKPoPK algorithm proposed in [7], the prover with a key pair (p​k,s​k)𝑝𝑘𝑠𝑘(pk,sk) can prove the knowledge of zero of a ciphertext u=𝖧𝖤.𝖤𝗇𝖼​(p​k,0,v)∈ℤn2formulae-sequence𝑢𝖧𝖤𝖤𝗇𝖼𝑝𝑘0𝑣subscriptℤsuperscript𝑛2u=\mathsf{HE.Enc}(pk,0,v)\in\mathbb{Z}_{n^{2}} to the honest verifier. Algorithm 4 provides details of the Paillier-based ZKPoPK of Zero algorithm b←𝖯𝖹𝖪𝖯𝗈𝖯𝖪𝗈𝖹​(n,u,p​k,s​k,v)←𝑏𝖯𝖹𝖪𝖯𝗈𝖯𝖪𝗈𝖹𝑛𝑢𝑝𝑘𝑠𝑘𝑣b\leftarrow\mathsf{PZKPoPKoZ}(n,u,pk,sk,v). The correctness and security proof are given in [7].

3 Security and Privacy Requirements

In general, the requirements of the proposed protocol are (i) both the client’s data and locally trained models cannot be learned by any other party, and (ii) the server achieves its training objective using FL while the weights indicate the real competence and productivity of clients. In particular, we divide our proposed scheme into two phases (i) data disparity evaluation where the server and each user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} jointly calculate the weight wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} based on the encrypted user’s local dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} and model ℳisubscriptℳ𝑖\mathcal{M}_{i}, and (ii) weighted aggregation where the server aggregates the model of each user ℳisubscriptℳ𝑖\mathcal{M}_{i} according to its weights wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i}. The scheme is dropout-resilient that allows at most n−t𝑛𝑡n-t dropout clients where t𝑡t is the threshold of the Shamir secret sharing scheme.

Threat model. Particularly, our protocol is secure against a malicious adversary controlling the central server and up to ⌈n3⌉+1𝑛31\lceil\frac{n}{3}\rceil+1 clients with the threshold t>⌊2​n3⌋+1𝑡2𝑛31t>\lfloor\frac{2n}{3}\rfloor+1 for the Shamir secret sharing scheme (because these bound are derived from secure aggregation scheme [4, 1] that we adapt to our proposed scheme, we refer interested readers to Appendix 0.D and [4] for the details). Both the clients and the central server can send fraudulent messages to each other. Note that we assume authenticated channels and the signature schemes to ensure the confidentiality and integrity of messages sent by participants, i.e., no Sybil attack (see the system setting in Section 5 for the details).

We consider only three types of active malicious behaviors, including (i) the user may publish the fraudulent weight (as we use HE for privately computing the weight, thus decryption is on the user-side, we will explain this in detail later), (ii) the user may upload the fraudulent locally trained model, and (iii) the server may give a different view of dropped users to the honest users during aggregation ( these operations are marked in underlined red in Protocol 1). The reason for such consideration is based on the following natures:

  • •

    The server is the party that intends to achieve the training objective using FL, and thus it would not deviate from the protocol before obtaining the real weights and models of users.

  • •

    The user will upload the encryption of real local dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} and model ℳisubscriptℳ𝑖\mathcal{M}_{i} for data disparity evaluation. This is because the user does not know how to modify them to obtain a larger weight value.

  • •

    The user may publish a fraudulent weight with a larger value than the real weight for its benefit.

  • •

    After getting the real weight, the user may upload a fraudulent model to affect the distribution of the global FL model in the current FL round to increase its weight in the next FL round [2].

  • •

    Since the list of dropped users is maintained by the server, the server may give a different view of dropped users to the honest users for malicious purposes, e.g., the server can claim an honest alive user to be dropped to ask other users to send its shares for recovering that user’s model or gradient.

High-level overview. Before proceeding to the phase for data disparity evaluation, each user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} uploads its encrypted dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} to the server S𝑆S. Note that those encrypted datasets are uploaded only once at the very beginning of FL. After that, in the phase for data disparity evaluation, the protocol works as follows: (i) each user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} uses its local dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} to train the model ℳisubscriptℳ𝑖\mathcal{M}_{i}, and send encrypted model ℳisubscriptℳ𝑖\mathcal{M}_{i} to the server. Then (ii) the server S𝑆S calculates the weight wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} following data disparity evaluation algorithm for each user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} using HE operations based on the received encrypted dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} and encrypted model ℳisubscriptℳ𝑖\mathcal{M}_{i} from each user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}. After that, (iii) the server S𝑆S sends encrypted weight wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} to the user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}, and finally (iv) the user decrypts the weight and publishes it to the server and other users. Note that the user holds the private key, and the decryption of weight is on the user-side. Thus, according to the threat model we discussed earlier, the server would not send fraudulent encrypted weight to each user, but the user may perform fraudulent decryption of the weight. Therefore, only the correctness of the decryption of weight on the user-side needs to be guaranteed. We adopt a variant of the ZKPoPK scheme to achieve such a goal (see Section 2.5.2). Besides, we notice that most of the HE operations for data disparity evaluation on the server-side are only with a ciphertext, i.e., encrypted data or model of the user, and a plaintext, i.e., server’s data or model. Thus, we can rely on the Paillier cryptosystem, which supports such HE operations instead of the less efficient Fully HE crypto-system (see Section 2.5.1 and Section 4.1).

In the second phase for weighted aggregation, a secure aggregation scheme [4, 1] provides a privacy guarantee against semi-honest and active adversaries. Note that the consistency check is adopted to deal with the issue regarding the central server assigning different views to honest clients, as mentioned earlier. Since we fully leverage this technique which is identical to the one used in the secure aggregation scheme, we describe it in Appendix 0.C and discuss the security of our proposed method in combination with consistency check, i.e., the maximum number of malicious adversaries allowed and the lower bound of the threshold t𝑡t for Shamir scheme, in Appendix 0.D. We follow the secure aggregation scheme in our work because it can be simply extended to secure weighted aggregation by uploading weighted models. However, an issue exists that users may upload fraudulent weighted models to the server for their benefits. For example, the clients can upload well-designed fraudulent models to affect the distribution of the global model of the current round to increase their weights in the next round [2]. Addressing such issues is not trivial as the solution may involve a complicated incentive mechanism and several protocols for security and privacy purposes. Luckily, since the real users’ models in ciphertext have already been uploaded to the server in the first phase, and the weight of each user are public, relying on the ZKPoPK algorithm, the server can require each user to prove the plaintext knowledge of its weighted model without conveying any information apart from the fact that whether the user uploads the real weighted model or not. We note that following the secure aggregation scheme, each weighted model wi​ℳisubscript𝑤𝑖subscriptℳ𝑖w_{i}\mathcal{M}_{i} to be uploaded is masked by adding some randomness Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{i}. In this case, each user needs to prove the plaintext knowledge of its masked weighted model wi​ℳi+Risubscript𝑤𝑖subscriptℳ𝑖subscript𝑅𝑖w_{i}\mathcal{M}_{i}+R_{i} instead of the weighted model wi​ℳisubscript𝑤𝑖subscriptℳ𝑖w_{i}\mathcal{M}_{i}, which requires the server to hold the ciphertext of the corresponding real masked weighted model. Since the encrypted masked weighted model can be obtained by adding the ciphertext of Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{i} to the ciphertext of the real weighted model, the problem boils down to ensuring the user honestly uploading the ciphertext of Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{i} to the server. In our scheme, we require users to upload these ciphertexts at the very beginning of each round of FL, such that users would not deviate from the protocol as they do not know how to design Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{i} to increase their weights for benefits without knowing the information of their weights and locally trained models in the current round.

4 Secure Weighted Aggregation Protocol

This section describes technical details of our privacy preserving scheme consisting for data disparity evaluation and weighted aggregation for federated learning.

4.1 Data Disparity Evaluation

For the phase of data disparity evaluation, we adopt a logistic regression model (see Section 2.2) and adapt the scheme proposed in [5] which enables the server to quantify the credibility of each user’s local dataset based on its label quality in a secure and privacy-preserving manner. Recall that the server S𝑆S maintains a benchmark dataset 𝒟s={(xs,ys)|s=1,2,…,ns}subscript𝒟𝑠conditional-setsubscript𝑥𝑠subscript𝑦𝑠𝑠12…subscript𝑛𝑠\mathcal{D}_{s}=\{(x_{s},y_{s})|s=1,2,\dots,n_{s}\} and a global FL model ℳℳ\mathcal{M}, and the user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} holds a local dataset 𝒟i={(xu,yu)|u=1,2,…,ni}subscript𝒟𝑖conditional-setsubscript𝑥𝑢subscript𝑦𝑢𝑢12…subscript𝑛𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}=\{(x_{u},y_{u})|u=1,2,\dots,n_{i}\} and a locally trained model ℳisubscriptℳ𝑖\mathcal{M}_{i} as well as a Paillier key pair (s​ki,p​ki)𝑠subscript𝑘𝑖𝑝subscript𝑘𝑖(sk_{i},pk_{i}).

The privacy-preserving data disparity evaluation works as follows (see Section 2.3 for the version over plaintext): (i) each user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} uses its p​ki𝑝subscript𝑘𝑖pk_{i} to encrypt its dataset and locally trained model as 𝖤𝗇𝖼(𝒟i)={(𝖤𝗇𝖼(xu),𝖤𝗇𝖼(yu))|\mathsf{Enc}(\mathcal{D}_{i})=\{(\mathsf{Enc}(x_{u}),\mathsf{Enc}(y_{u}))| u=1,2,…,ni}u=1,2,\dots,n_{i}\} and 𝖤𝗇𝖼​(ℳi)𝖤𝗇𝖼subscriptℳ𝑖\mathsf{Enc}(\mathcal{M}_{i}) respectively, and uploads them to the server. This means that Equation 2 can be directly evaluated using Paillier and Equation 3 needs one more round for computation. Specifically, let 𝖤𝗇𝖼​(h)=log⁡P​(y∣𝖤𝗇𝖼​(xu);ℳs)𝖤𝗇𝖼ℎ𝑃conditional𝑦𝖤𝗇𝖼subscript𝑥𝑢superscriptℳ𝑠\mathsf{Enc}(h)=\log P\left(y\mid\mathsf{Enc}(x_{u});\mathcal{M}^{s}\right) in Equation 3, the server first sends 𝖤𝗇𝖼​(h)𝖤𝗇𝖼ℎ\mathsf{Enc}(h) to the user for decryption. To protect hℎh which may leak information of x𝑥x against the server, the user decrypts 𝖤𝗇𝖼​(h)𝖤𝗇𝖼ℎ\mathsf{Enc}(h) and masks hℎh using a randomly chosen value r𝑟r then sends h+rℎ𝑟h+r to the server (here the user may send fraudulent h+rℎ𝑟h+r). Following that, the server computes 𝖤𝗇𝖼​(yu​h+yu​r)=𝖤𝗇𝖼​(yu)​(h+r)𝖤𝗇𝖼subscript𝑦𝑢ℎsubscript𝑦𝑢𝑟𝖤𝗇𝖼subscript𝑦𝑢ℎ𝑟\mathsf{Enc}(y_{u}h+y_{u}r)=\mathsf{Enc}(y_{u})(h+r). Assume that 𝖤𝗇𝖼​(yu​r)𝖤𝗇𝖼subscript𝑦𝑢𝑟\mathsf{Enc}(y_{u}r) has been uploaded to the server, the server is able to compute 𝖤𝗇𝖼​(yu​h)=𝖤𝗇𝖼​(yu​h+yu​r)⊞𝖤𝗇𝖼​(−yu​r)𝖤𝗇𝖼subscript𝑦𝑢ℎ⊞𝖤𝗇𝖼subscript𝑦𝑢ℎsubscript𝑦𝑢𝑟𝖤𝗇𝖼subscript𝑦𝑢𝑟\mathsf{Enc}(y_{u}h)=\mathsf{Enc}(y_{u}h+y_{u}r)\boxplus\mathsf{Enc}(-y_{u}r). Note that r𝑟r is secure even if the server holds 𝖤𝗇𝖼​(yu)𝖤𝗇𝖼subscript𝑦𝑢\mathsf{Enc}(y_{u}) and 𝖤𝗇𝖼​(yu​r)𝖤𝗇𝖼subscript𝑦𝑢𝑟\mathsf{Enc}(y_{u}r). Such security is provided by the IND-CPA property of Paillier (see Section 2.5.1 and Appendix 0.B). In addition, for computing binary cross-entropy after sigmod function, we can further simplify the polynomial replacement of their combined function using the similar above mentioned method.

After that, (iii) each user i𝑖i uses its private key s​ki𝑠subscript𝑘𝑖sk_{i} to decrypt 𝖤𝗇𝖼​(Ei)𝖤𝗇𝖼subscript𝐸𝑖\mathsf{Enc}(E_{i}) and publishes Eisubscript𝐸𝑖E_{i}. Finally (iv) all participants can compute the credibility Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i} and weight wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} for each user i𝑖i following:

wi=ni​Ci∑k=1Knk​Ci=ni​eα​R​Ei∑knk​eα​R​Ek​, such that​∑iwi=1subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝐶𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑛𝑘subscript𝐶𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖superscript𝑒𝛼𝑅subscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝑘subscript𝑛𝑘superscript𝑒𝛼𝑅subscript𝐸𝑘, such thatsubscript𝑖subscript𝑤𝑖1\displaystyle w_{i}=\frac{n_{i}C_{i}}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}n_{k}C_{i}}=\frac{n_{i}e^{\alpha{}RE_{i}}}{\sum_{k}n_{k}e^{\alpha{}RE_{k}}}\text{, such that}\sum_{i}w_{i}=1 (5)

where

Ci=eα​R​Ei∑keα​R​Ek,R​Ei=1Eiformulae-sequencesubscript𝐶𝑖superscript𝑒𝛼𝑅subscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝑘superscript𝑒𝛼𝑅subscript𝐸𝑘𝑅subscript𝐸𝑖1subscript𝐸𝑖C_{i}=\frac{e^{\alpha RE_{i}}}{\sum_{k}e^{\alpha RE_{k}}},\ RE_{i}=\frac{1}{E_{i}}

Here, Equation 5 is the adapted version of that in [5] in order to handle dropout case by simply adjusting the denominator of wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} in Equation 5 on server-side during subsequent weighted aggregation (see Section 4.2).

As discussed in Section 3, since the user i𝑖i may deviate from the protocol for its benefit by publishing fraudulent decryption of Eisubscript𝐸𝑖E_{i} in step (iii) especially when there is an incentive mechanism where reward provided by the server is distributed according to clients’ weights, a verification scheme is needed to guarantee the correct decryption of Eisubscript𝐸𝑖E_{i} on the user-side. To address this issue, we construct a variant of the ZKPoPK of Zero algorithm given in Section 2.5.2 to enable a user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} with a key pair (p​ki,s​ki)𝑝subscript𝑘𝑖𝑠subscript𝑘𝑖(pk_{i},sk_{i}) to convince the server S𝑆S the fact that a message m𝑚m is the correct decryption of ciphertext c𝑐c. To do so, given the message m𝑚m, the server can compute c′=c−𝖤𝗇𝖼​(m)superscript𝑐′𝑐𝖤𝗇𝖼𝑚c^{\prime}=c-\mathsf{Enc}(m) and then requires the user to prove the knowledge of zero of the ciphertext c′superscript𝑐′c^{\prime} following Algorithm 4. The detail of this algorithm is given in Algorithm 2.

Assume that the server receives a message Ei′superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑖′E_{i}^{\prime} which is the decryption of 𝖤𝗇𝖼​(Ei)𝖤𝗇𝖼subscript𝐸𝑖\mathsf{Enc}(E_{i}) from the user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}. Following Algorithm 2, the server S𝑆S and the user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} get β←𝖯𝖯𝗈𝖯𝖪(𝖤𝗇𝖼(Ei),\beta\leftarrow\mathsf{PPoPK}(\mathsf{Enc}(E_{i}), Ei′,superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑖′E_{i}^{\prime}, pki,ski)pk_{i},sk_{i}). The server accepts Ei′superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑖′E_{i}^{\prime} as the plaintext of 𝖤𝗇𝖼​(Ei)𝖤𝗇𝖼subscript𝐸𝑖\mathsf{Enc}(E_{i}) if and only if β=1𝛽1\beta=1, which means the user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} honestly decrypts 𝖤𝗇𝖼​(Ei)𝖤𝗇𝖼subscript𝐸𝑖\mathsf{Enc}(E_{i}). Otherwise, the server refuses the message Ei′superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑖′E_{i}^{\prime} and removes the user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} from the user set for aggregation. Similar approach can be adopted to guarantee the correct decryption of hℎh in step (ii). The correctness and security proof of the algorithm 4 can be found in Appendix 0.A.

4.2 Weighted Aggregation

After each weight of the user is determined after the phase of data disparity evaluation, the server collects all locally trained models from users and aggregates them to update the global model ℳℳ\mathcal{M} according to their corresponding weights:

ℳ=∑ui∈𝒰′wi​ℳi, such that​∑ui∈𝒰′wi=1formulae-sequenceℳsubscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖superscript𝒰′subscript𝑤𝑖subscriptℳ𝑖 such thatsubscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖superscript𝒰′subscript𝑤𝑖1\mathcal{M}=\sum_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}^{\prime}}w_{i}\mathcal{M}_{i},\text{ such that}\sum_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U^{\prime}}}w_{i}=1

where wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} and ℳisubscriptℳ𝑖\mathcal{M}_{i} are the weight and local model of user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}, and 𝒰′superscript𝒰′\mathcal{U}^{\prime} is the selected user set in the current round of FL.

Let the numerator of wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} in Equation 5 be ωi=ni​eα​R​Eisubscript𝜔𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖superscript𝑒𝛼𝑅subscript𝐸𝑖\omega_{i}=n_{i}e^{\alpha RE_{i}}, we can rewrite Equation 5:

ℳ=1∑uj∈𝒰′nj​eα​R​Ej​∑ui∈𝒰′ωi​ℳiℳ1subscriptsubscript𝑢𝑗superscript𝒰′subscript𝑛𝑗superscript𝑒𝛼𝑅subscript𝐸𝑗subscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖superscript𝒰′subscript𝜔𝑖subscriptℳ𝑖\mathcal{M}=\frac{1}{\sum_{u_{j}\in\mathcal{U^{\prime}}}n_{j}e^{\alpha RE_{j}}}\sum_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}^{\prime}}\omega_{i}\mathcal{M}_{i} (6)

Therefore, the server can deal with dropout users by adjusting 𝒰′superscript𝒰′\mathcal{U}^{\prime} and aggregates all alive models from users following the secure aggregation scheme [1, 4].

To prevent users from uploading fraudulent weighted models to the server, as we discussed in Section 3, a ZKPoPK based verification scheme is attached. The main idea of such a verification scheme is that if the server holds the encryption of each real masked weighted model c​yi𝑐subscript𝑦𝑖cy_{i}, it can verify if the user uploads its real masked weighted model yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} by checking the equality between yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} and the decryption of c​yi𝑐subscript𝑦𝑖cy_{i}. Specifically, relying on the verification Algorithm 2, each user needs to prove the plaintext knowledge of its masked weighted model ωi​ℳi+Risubscript𝜔𝑖subscriptℳ𝑖subscript𝑅𝑖\omega_{i}\mathcal{M}_{i}+R_{i} instead of the weighted model ωi​ℳisubscript𝜔𝑖subscriptℳ𝑖\omega_{i}\mathcal{M}_{i}, which requires the server to hold the ciphertext of the corresponding real masked weighted model. This means that each user ui∈𝒰′subscript𝑢𝑖superscript𝒰′u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}^{\prime} has to upload its encrypted mask 𝖤𝗇𝖼​(Ri)𝖤𝗇𝖼subscript𝑅𝑖\mathsf{Enc}(R_{i}) to the server, and the server computes the real encryption of each masked weighted model yi′superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖′y_{i}^{\prime} as:

yi′=ωi⊠𝖤𝗇𝖼​(ℳi)⊞𝖤𝗇𝖼​(Ri)superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖′⊞⊠subscript𝜔𝑖𝖤𝗇𝖼subscriptℳ𝑖𝖤𝗇𝖼subscript𝑅𝑖y_{i}^{\prime}=\omega_{i}\boxtimes\mathsf{Enc}(\mathcal{M}_{i})\boxplus\mathsf{Enc}(R_{i}) (7)

Note that the 𝖤𝗇𝖼​(Ri)𝖤𝗇𝖼subscript𝑅𝑖\mathsf{Enc}(R_{i}) should be uploaded before the model aggregation step according to the analysis in Section 3 to prevent the user from manipulating Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{i} for their benefits. Besides, since ωisubscript𝜔𝑖\omega_{i} is a public value and 𝖤𝗇𝖼​(ℳi)𝖤𝗇𝖼subscriptℳ𝑖\mathsf{Enc}(\mathcal{M}_{i}) has been uploaded during data disparity evaluation, the server can calculate yi′superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖′y_{i}^{\prime} using Pallier HE operations.

The detailed description of our secure weighted aggregation scheme for one FL round is given in Protocol 1. Note that the Setup step is only performed once at the very beginning of federated learning. Step 00 to step 444 are performed in every FL round.

4.3 Discussion on Privacy and Security

The security of our proposed scheme can be derived from the reasonable assumptions for the FL system as described in Section 3, and the security of underlay cryptographic building blocks. Recall that the requirements of the proposed scheme are to ensure the privacy of the client’s local dataset and model, and security against fraudulent messages (weight, model, and view of dropped user list).

First, we give the discussion from the angle of privacy protection. Since both the client’s dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} and locally trained model ℳisubscriptℳ𝑖\mathcal{M}_{i} are encrypted using Paillier crypto-system in step Setup and step 1, then uploaded to the server, the server learns nothing from the ciphertext. After that, during computing the weight in step 1, HE operations are applied, and thus additions between ciphertexts do not leak any information. For computing a polynomial f​(l)𝑓𝑙f(l) which consists of multiplication between ciphertexts where the server keeps Enc​(l)Enc𝑙\text{Enc}(l), a trick is adopted as described in Section 2.3. The main idea is to use a random r𝑟r to mask l𝑙l to enable the computation f​(l+r)𝑓𝑙𝑟f(l+r) over plaintext, then deduct the redundant terms of f​(l+r)𝑓𝑙𝑟f(l+r) to obtain the encryption of f​(l)𝑓𝑙f(l) using HE. The security of the trick is based on that the client does not know the value of r𝑟r. Note that this trick enables the client to have the ciphertext of both r𝑟r and the a​r𝑎𝑟ar where a𝑎a is a public value. Privacy is still guaranteed thanks to the IND-CPA property (see Section 2.5.1 and Appendix 0.B) of Paillier crypto-system. The privacy of the public masked weighted model wi​ℳi+Risubscript𝑤𝑖subscriptℳ𝑖subscript𝑅𝑖w_{i}\mathcal{M}_{i}+R_{i} in step 3 and step 4 is protected by the mask Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{i} randomly chosen by the client uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}, and the secure aggregation scheme. Therefore, there is no information leakage of both client’s local dataset and model during the execution of our proposed protocol.

Next, we discuss from the angle of security against fraudulent messages. According to the assumptions described in Section 3, the server has the encryption of the real client’s model yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i}, real mutual cross-entropy Eisubscript𝐸𝑖E_{i}, and real mask Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{i} after step setup, step 0, and step 1. Since zero-knowledge proof is adopted in step 2 to ensure the correct decryption of Eisubscript𝐸𝑖E_{i}, both the server and client can compute real wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i}. Then the server can compute the encryption of real masked weighted model wi​ℳi+Risubscript𝑤𝑖subscriptℳ𝑖subscript𝑅𝑖w_{i}\mathcal{M}_{i}+R_{i}, which can be used to ensure that the client uploads the plaintext of the real masked weighted model using zero-knowledge proof in step 3. The security regarding the view of dropped user list is provided by the consistency check technique (see Appendix 0.C) used in the secure aggregation scheme. Therefore, our scheme guarantees security against fraudulent messages, i.e., the correctness of both weight, model, and dropped user list.

5 Performance Analysis

System setting. Our prototype is tested over two Linux workstations with an Intel Xeon E5-2603v4 CPU (1.70GHz) and 64 GB of RAM, running CentOS 7 in the same region. The average latency of the network is 0.207 ms, and the average bandwidth is 1.25 GB/s. The central server runs in multi-thread on one workstation, while the users are running in parallel in the other workstation. In our experiments, original data is represented in fixed-point with 44 bits, including 17 bits for the integer part and 27 bits for the fractional part. The ring size N𝑁N for Paillier is set to be a 1024-bit integer, and the security parameter κ𝜅\kappa is set to be 808080. We use AES-GCM with 128-bit keys for authenticated channels, and adopt the state-of-the-art secure aggregation scheme (Secagg+ [1]) for dropout-resilient aggregation. The performance is evaluated on Credit Card Clients dataset from the UCI ML repository [8], from which each user randomly chooses samples with the same size to construct its local dataset. The number of samples in the benchmark dataset on the server-side is set to be 500.

As seen in Figure 1(a) and 1(b), the run time and communication cost for 𝖯𝖯𝗈𝖯𝖪𝖯𝖯𝗈𝖯𝖪\mathsf{PPoPK} increase almost linearly with the dimensions of input m𝑚m. Figure 2(a) and 2(b) show the run time and communication cost of a client in the first phase, i.e., data disparity evaluation, including CompE and PoKE. Both the run time and communication costs increase linearly with the number of samples in the local dataset. Figure 3(a) and 3(b) give the performance on total run time and communication cost of the second phase, i.e., weighted aggregation, including PoKM and Wagg, compared with the model aggregation counterpart in secure aggregation scheme (Secagg) [4] and the improved secure aggregation scheme (Secagg+) [1]. Note that the dropped users in our scheme include both the users that do not pass PoKM and the users that drop out of the system. The results show that our scheme provides an additional security guarantee against fraudulent messages with affordable overheads compared to the previous works. In particular, our scheme achieves around 1.2 times in run time and 1.3 times in communication cost upon the state-of-the-art secure aggregation scheme Secagg+, which indicates the practicality of our scheme. Table 1 lists the run time and communication costs of the user and server for each step in one FL round with different dropout rates in the first phase for data disparity evaluation R1subscript𝑅1R_{1}, and the second phase for weighted aggregation R2subscript𝑅2R_{2}. Note that the server’s run time is the run time of the whole FL system, and we treat the users who do not pass PoKE and PoKM as dropout users as demonstrated in Protocol 1. In specific, we consider the ”worst-case” dropout scenario where the users drop out during PoKE in the first phase as the server has already completed the calculation of the weights, or PoKM in the second phase as the users have already uploaded their weighted models. We can observe that dropout users cause a significant increasement in the total run time because of the high cost of dealing with dropout users in the underlying secure aggregation scheme.

6 Discussion on Related Works

There have been several schemes proposed to perform privacy-preserving and dropout-resilient aggregation. The main idea of these schemes is to integrate FL with privacy-preserving techniques such as DP, HE, and MPC. For example, the authors in [16] propose a DP-based FL scheme that a level of noise is added to each client’s locally trained model before aggregation, and thus to hide clients’ data distribution. However, there is a trade-off between privacy loss and model performance.

For the HE-based aggregation scheme, in every round of FL, each client’s locally trained model is encrypted before uploading. Then the central server aggregates the clients’ model in ciphertext using HE operations and publishes the result for decryption. In this scheme, the private key is distributed among all participants relying on a threshold HE crypto-system, e.g., [18], and several parties that more than a threshold number can jointly decrypt an encrypted message. Although the HE-based scheme provides an exact solution for privacy-preserving aggregation compared with the DP-based scheme, it may incur infeasible cost overhead for a large-scale FL system as the underlying threshold crypto-system requires all participants to contribute to several expensive protocols. Besides, this scheme cannot deal with clients dropping out.

A more efficient and dropout-robust aggregation scheme providing an exact solution is based on MPC, as proposed in [4]. In this scheme, each client’s locally trained model is masked that the seeds for generating masks are secretly shared among all clients using a threshold secret sharing scheme to handle the dropout users. The improved version [1] upon [4] replaces the complete communication graph in [4] with a k𝑘k-regular graph to further reduce the communication overheads. Another variant TurboAgg [20] divides clients into multiple groups and follows a multi-group circular structure for communication. FastSecAgg [12] substitutes threshold secret sharing with FFT-based multi-secret sharing scheme. NIKE [14] adopts a non-interactive key exchange protocol relying on non-colluding servers.

Note that for a large-scale FL system, executions of threshold secret sharing operations are more cost-effective than that of a threshold HE crypto-system. Nevertheless, all of the schemes mentioned above focus on achieving FL from a privacy-preserving perspective, issues still exist that both the central server and clients may send fraudulent messages to each other for their benefits.

7 Conclusion

In this paper, we proposed a privacy-enhanced FL scheme for supporting secure weighted aggregation. Our scheme is able to deal with both data disparity, data privacy, and dishonest participants (who send fraudulent messages to manipulate the computed weights) in FL systems. The proposed scheme leverages on HE and zero-knowledge proof (ZKP), and combines with a dropout-resilient secure aggregation scheme. Experimental results show that our scheme is practical and secure. Compared to existing FL approaches, our scheme achieves secure weighted aggregation with an additional security guarantee against fraudulent messages with affordable runtime overheads and communication costs.

For future research investigation, we will substitute the Paillier cryptosystem with other HE schemes such as CKKS [6] in order to improve the efficiency of data disparity evaluation. Several other attacks such as membership inference attack [19] and model inversion attack [9] will be taken into account for a more general threat model. Besides, other distributed machine learning schemes such as split learning [11] can be integrated to further reduce the computation overheads on the client-side to make FL more friendly to resource-constrained edge devices.

Appendix 0.A Proof of Algorithm 4

The correctness is proved as follows. Theorem 0.A.1 (Security against malicious users)

The Paillier-based Proof of Plaintext Knowledge is secure against malicious users. If there exists a probabilistic polynomial time (PPT) adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} with Paillier key pair (s​k,p​k)𝑠𝑘𝑝𝑘(sk,pk) providing a fraudulent plaintext m′superscript𝑚′m^{\prime} as the decryption of c𝑐c that 𝖧𝖤.𝖣𝖾𝖼​(s​k,c)≠m′formulae-sequence𝖧𝖤𝖣𝖾𝖼𝑠𝑘𝑐superscript𝑚′\mathsf{HE.Dec}(sk,c)\neq m^{\prime}. The probability of the server accepting the fraudulent decryption 𝖯𝗋​[1←𝖯𝖯𝗈𝖯𝖪𝒜​(c,m′,p​k,s​k)]⩽2−k/2𝖯𝗋delimited-[]←1subscript𝖯𝖯𝗈𝖯𝖪𝒜𝑐superscript𝑚′𝑝𝑘𝑠𝑘superscript2𝑘2\mathsf{Pr}[1\leftarrow\mathsf{PPoPK}_{\mathcal{A}}(c,m^{\prime},pk,sk)]\leqslant 2^{-k/2} where k𝑘k is the bit length of n𝑛n as the Paillier public key.

Proof

Assume that a PPT adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} with key pair (s​k,p​k)𝑠𝑘𝑝𝑘(sk,pk) provides a fraudulent decryption m′superscript𝑚′m^{\prime} of a ciphertext c𝑐c, while 𝖧𝖤.𝖣𝖾𝖼formulae-sequence𝖧𝖤𝖣𝖾𝖼\mathsf{HE.Dec} (s​k,c)𝑠𝑘𝑐(sk,c) =mabsent𝑚=m and m≠m′𝑚superscript𝑚′m\neq m^{\prime}, the server accepts m′superscript𝑚′m^{\prime} only if 1←𝖯𝖯𝗈𝖯𝖪(c,1\leftarrow\mathsf{PPoPK}(c, m′,pk,sk)m^{\prime},pk,sk). Given the algorithm 2, the server randomly chooses rs∈ℤn∗subscript𝑟𝑠superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑛r_{s}\in\mathbb{Z}_{n}^{*} to compute c′=c−𝖧𝖤.𝖤𝗇𝖼​(p​ki,m′,rs)(modn2)=𝖤𝗇𝖼​(m−m′)formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑐′𝑐𝖧𝖤annotated𝖤𝗇𝖼𝑝subscript𝑘𝑖superscript𝑚′subscript𝑟𝑠moduloabsentsuperscript𝑛2𝖤𝗇𝖼𝑚superscript𝑚′c^{\prime}=c-\mathsf{HE.Enc}(pk_{i},m^{\prime},r_{s})(\bmod\ n^{2})=\mathsf{Enc}(m-m^{\prime}) and sends c′superscript𝑐′c^{\prime} to the adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. Therefore, the security of 𝖯𝖯𝗈𝖯𝖪𝖯𝖯𝗈𝖯𝖪\mathsf{PPoPK} follows from the security of 𝖯𝖹𝖪𝖯𝗈𝖯𝖪𝗈𝖹𝖯𝖹𝖪𝖯𝗈𝖯𝖪𝗈𝖹\mathsf{PZKPoPKoZ} such that the probability of the adversary make the server accept the fraudulent decryption m′superscript𝑚′m^{\prime} is less than 2−k/2superscript2𝑘22^{-k/2} where k𝑘k is the bit length of n𝑛n as the Paillier public key.

Appendix 0.B Indistinguishability under chosen-plaintext attack (IND-CPA)

Definition 1 (IND-CPA)

Let 𝖧𝖤=(𝖪𝖾𝗒𝖦𝖾𝗇,\mathsf{HE}=(\mathsf{KeyGen},𝖤𝗇𝖼,𝖤𝗇𝖼\mathsf{Enc},𝖣𝖾𝖼)\mathsf{Dec}) be a homomorphic encryption scheme, and 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} be a probabilistic polynomial-time (PPT) adversary. Consider the following experiment:
𝐄𝐗𝐏𝖧𝖤,𝒜𝖨𝖭𝖣−𝖢𝖯𝖠​(λ)superscriptsubscript𝐄𝐗𝐏𝖧𝖤𝒜𝖨𝖭𝖣𝖢𝖯𝖠𝜆\mathbf{EXP}_{\mathsf{HE},\mathcal{A}}^{\mathsf{IND-CPA}}(\lambda):

  • (1)

    b←${0,1}superscript←currency-dollar𝑏01b\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\$}}{{\leftarrow}}\{0,1\}, {p​k,s​k}←$𝖧𝖤.𝖪𝖾𝗒𝖦𝖾𝗇​(p,q)formulae-sequencesuperscript←currency-dollar𝑝𝑘𝑠𝑘𝖧𝖤𝖪𝖾𝗒𝖦𝖾𝗇𝑝𝑞\{pk,sk\}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\$}}{{\leftarrow}}\mathsf{HE.KeyGen}(p,q)

  • (2)

    (m0,m1)←𝒜​(p​k)←subscript𝑚0subscript𝑚1𝒜𝑝𝑘(m_{0},m_{1})\leftarrow\mathcal{A}(pk)

  • (3)

    c←𝖧𝖤.𝖤𝗇𝖼​(p​k,mb,r)formulae-sequence←𝑐𝖧𝖤𝖤𝗇𝖼𝑝𝑘subscript𝑚𝑏𝑟c\leftarrow\mathsf{HE.Enc}(pk,m_{b},r)

  • (4)

    b′←𝒜​(c)←superscript𝑏′𝒜𝑐b^{\prime}\leftarrow\mathcal{A}(c)

  • (5)

    Output 111 if b=b′𝑏superscript𝑏′b=b^{\prime}, 0 o/w.

Define the advantage of the adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} as

𝐀𝐝𝐯𝖧𝖤,𝒜𝖨𝖭𝖣−𝖢𝖯𝖠​(λ):=|𝖯𝗋​[𝐄𝐗𝐏𝖧𝖤,𝒜𝖨𝖭𝖣−𝖢𝖯𝖠​(λ)=1]−12|assignsuperscriptsubscript𝐀𝐝𝐯𝖧𝖤𝒜𝖨𝖭𝖣𝖢𝖯𝖠𝜆𝖯𝗋delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐄𝐗𝐏𝖧𝖤𝒜𝖨𝖭𝖣𝖢𝖯𝖠𝜆112\mathbf{Adv}_{\mathsf{HE},\mathcal{A}}^{\mathsf{IND-CPA}}(\lambda):=|\mathsf{Pr}[\mathbf{EXP}_{\mathsf{HE},\mathcal{A}}^{\mathsf{IND-CPA}}(\lambda)=1]-\frac{1}{2}|

Then we say such HE scheme is indistinguishable under chosen-plaintext attack if for any PPT adversariy 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, there exists a negligible function 𝗇𝖾𝗀𝗅​(⋅)𝗇𝖾𝗀𝗅⋅\mathsf{negl}(\cdot) such that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} as 𝐀𝐝𝐯𝖧𝖤,𝒜𝖨𝖭𝖣−𝖢𝖯𝖠​(λ)⩽𝗇𝖾𝗀𝗅​(λ)superscriptsubscript𝐀𝐝𝐯𝖧𝖤𝒜𝖨𝖭𝖣𝖢𝖯𝖠𝜆𝗇𝖾𝗀𝗅𝜆\mathbf{Adv}_{\mathsf{HE},\mathcal{A}}^{\mathsf{IND-CPA}}(\lambda)\leqslant\mathsf{negl}(\lambda).

Paillier crypto-system provides semantic security against chosen-plaintext attacks (IND-CPA). The challenge of successfully distinguishing ciphertext essentially can be deducted to deciding composite residuosity, which is believed to be intractable. Thus, an adversary will be unable to distinguish pairs of ciphertexts based on the message they encrypt using Paillier crypto-system [17].

Appendix 0.C Consistency Check

Consistency check guarantees that a set of users of which the number is greater than the threshold t𝑡t for the Shamir scheme have the same view of dropped users (see [4, 1] for the detailed security proof). To achieve this goal, consistency check heavily leverage signature schemes which can be used to prove the origin of a message. Denote a signature scheme as (ℱk​g,ℱs​i​g,ℱv​r​f​y)subscriptℱ𝑘𝑔subscriptℱ𝑠𝑖𝑔subscriptℱ𝑣𝑟𝑓𝑦(\mathcal{F}_{kg},\mathcal{F}_{sig},\mathcal{F}_{vrfy}). Randomised algorithm ℱk​g→(s​k,p​k)→subscriptℱ𝑘𝑔𝑠𝑘𝑝𝑘\mathcal{F}_{kg}\rightarrow(sk,pk) outputs a secret key s​k𝑠𝑘sk and a public key p​k𝑝𝑘pk. Randomised algorithm ℱs​i​g​(m,s​k)→δ→subscriptℱ𝑠𝑖𝑔𝑚𝑠𝑘𝛿\mathcal{F}_{sig}(m,sk)\rightarrow\delta uses s​k𝑠𝑘sk to assign a signature δ𝛿\delta on the message m𝑚m. Deterministic algorithm ℱv​r​f​y​(m,p​k,δ)→{0,1}→subscriptℱ𝑣𝑟𝑓𝑦𝑚𝑝𝑘𝛿01\mathcal{F}_{vrfy}(m,pk,\delta)\rightarrow\{0,1\} takes in the p​k𝑝𝑘pk, m𝑚m, δ𝛿\delta and returns 111 if δ𝛿\delta is a signature on m𝑚m and 00 otherwise. Assume each alive user u∈𝒰a𝑢subscript𝒰𝑎u\in\mathcal{U}_{a} has a key pair (s​ku,p​ku)𝑠subscript𝑘𝑢𝑝subscript𝑘𝑢(sk_{u},pk_{u}), and the server has a key pair (s​ks,p​ks)𝑠subscript𝑘𝑠𝑝subscript𝑘𝑠(sk_{s},pk_{s}) generated using ℱk​gsubscriptℱ𝑘𝑔\mathcal{F}_{kg}. The server maintains the list of alive users as 𝒰lsubscript𝒰𝑙\mathcal{U}_{l}. Consistency check works as follows:

  1. 1.

    Each user u∈𝒰a𝑢subscript𝒰𝑎u\in\mathcal{U}_{a} fetches the list of 𝒰lsubscript𝒰𝑙\mathcal{U}_{l} from the server, denoted as 𝒰lusuperscriptsubscript𝒰𝑙𝑢\mathcal{U}_{l}^{u}.

  2. 2.

    Each user u∈𝒰a𝑢subscript𝒰𝑎u\in\mathcal{U}_{a} assigns the signature on received 𝒰lusuperscriptsubscript𝒰𝑙𝑢\mathcal{U}_{l}^{u} as ℱs​i​g​(𝒰lu,s​ku)→δu→subscriptℱ𝑠𝑖𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒰𝑙𝑢𝑠subscript𝑘𝑢subscript𝛿𝑢\mathcal{F}_{sig}(\mathcal{U}_{l}^{u},sk_{u})\rightarrow\delta_{u}, and send (𝒰lu,δu)superscriptsubscript𝒰𝑙𝑢subscript𝛿𝑢(\mathcal{U}_{l}^{u},\delta_{u}) to the server.

  3. 3.

    The server receives (𝒰lu,δu)superscriptsubscript𝒰𝑙𝑢subscript𝛿𝑢(\mathcal{U}_{l}^{u},\delta_{u}) from at least t𝑡t users to build a list denoted as 𝒰l′superscriptsubscript𝒰𝑙′\mathcal{U}_{l}^{\prime}, and forwards them to the user u∈𝒰a𝑢subscript𝒰𝑎u\in\mathcal{U}_{a}.

  4. 4.

    For each user u∈𝒰a𝑢subscript𝒰𝑎u\in\mathcal{U}_{a}, if |𝒰l′|<tsuperscriptsubscript𝒰𝑙′𝑡|\mathcal{U}_{l}^{\prime}|<t or 𝒰l′⊄𝒰lnot-subset-ofsuperscriptsubscript𝒰𝑙′subscript𝒰𝑙\mathcal{U}_{l}^{\prime}\not\subset\mathcal{U}_{l}, abort.

Note that consistency check provides the privacy guarantee against active adversaries only when the threshold t𝑡t is set to be a proper value. We discuss its bounds in Appendix 0.D.

Appendix 0.D Discussion on Tolerance

Next, we discuss the maximum number of malicious adversaries allowed and the lower bound of the threshold t𝑡t for the Shamir scheme. Recall that there are n𝑛n clients including nasubscript𝑛𝑎n_{a} malicious clients. Let the number of signatures from honest clients on two list l1subscript𝑙1l_{1}, l2subscript𝑙2l_{2} be n1subscript𝑛1n_{1} and n2subscript𝑛2n_{2} respectively, and the number of signatures from malicious clients is nasubscript𝑛𝑎n_{a}. To have both l1subscript𝑙1l_{1} and l2subscript𝑙2l_{2} to pass the consistency check, the number of signatures on them should be greater than the threshold t𝑡t such that n1+na≥t,n2+na≥tformulae-sequencesubscript𝑛1subscript𝑛𝑎𝑡subscript𝑛2subscript𝑛𝑎𝑡n_{1}+n_{a}\geq t,n_{2}+n_{a}\geq t, subject to n1+n2+na≤nsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑛2subscript𝑛𝑎𝑛n_{1}+n_{2}+n_{a}\leq n. To guarantee the security, we have t≥n+na2𝑡𝑛subscript𝑛𝑎2t\geq\frac{n+n_{a}}{2}. Beside, since the server cannot the forge signatures of the honest parties, there is no two sets that 2​(t−na)≤n−na2𝑡subscript𝑛𝑎𝑛subscript𝑛𝑎2(t-n_{a})\leq n-n_{a} which implies the maximum number of malicious adversaries allowed is ⌈n3⌉−1𝑛31\lceil\frac{n}{3}\rceil-1, and thus the lower bound threshold t𝑡t is ⌊2​n3⌋+12𝑛31\lfloor\frac{2n}{3}\rfloor+1. Since ⌈n3⌉−1<⌊2​n3⌋+1≤t𝑛312𝑛31𝑡\lceil\frac{n}{3}\rceil-1<\lfloor\frac{2n}{3}\rfloor+1\leq t, the security of Shamir secret sharing scheme is also guaranteed. More details about the derivation of the above-mentioned bounds can be found in [4]. Note that dropped users do not affect the privacy and security of step setup and step 0-3, as each client executes the protocol with the server independently. Therefore, the bounds of the number of malicious adversaries and threshold regarding tolerance still follow those of the secure aggregation scheme.
